column1: Kingston is a city in and the county seat of Ulster County
column2: New York
column3: United States. It is 91 miles (146 km) north of New York City and 59 miles (95 km) south of Albany. The city's metropolitan area is grouped with the New York metropolitan area around Manhattan by the United States Census Bureau

column1: It became New York's first capital in 1777. During the American Revolutionary War
column2: the city was burned by the British on October 13
column4: after the Battles of Saratoga.

column2: the city became an important transport hub after the discovery of natural cement in the region. It had connections to other markets through both the railroad and canal connections.

column1: Many of the older buildings are considered contributing as part of three historic districts
column2: including the Stockade District uptown
column3: the Midtown Neighborhood Broadway Corridor
column4: and the Rondout-West Strand Historic District downtown. Each district is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: Successive cultures of humans are believed to have been settled on the land that is today Kingston for at least 13
column2: 000 years. Before colonization
column3: the two main historic tribes on the land were the Esopus (a band of the larger Lenape tribe
column4: also known as the Delaware) and the Mohican. The Lenape had three major dialect groups and occupied territory along the mid-Atlantic coast extending from Connecticut
column5: through the Lower Hudson River Valley (including the southern parts of Kingston)
column6: parts of Pennsylvania
column7: and into New Jersey on both sides of the Delaware River
column8: and in Eastern Delaware. The exact population of the Lenape is unknown but estimated to have been around 10
column9: 000 people in 1600. In the Kingston area
column10: the Lenape spoke a dialect called Munsee.

column1: The Esopus existed peacefully with their northern Mohican neighbors
column2: who occupied the land of Northern Kingston and into parts of present-day Vermont
column3: Massachusetts
column4: and Connecticut. The tribes traded
column5: protected one another from attack
column6: and recognized common interests for land protection. They never formed a broader
column7: more official alliance as did some other nations in the area
column8: such as those of the Iroquois League in New York and the Pequot in New England.

column1: Both tribes lived in small communities of relatives ranging in groups from 10-100 people. They moved seasonally between camps to follow game
column2: fish
column3: and produce. The women developed diverse and sophisticated agricultural practices
column4: cultivating different types of squash
column5: maize (corn) and beans. The community enjoyed a range of many types of corn
column6: beans
column8: in addition to the produce the women would gather: hickory and other nuts
column10: and roots. Men hunted for large and small game
column17: and bears. They also caught fish in the rivers.

column2: the Dutch had set up a factorij (trading post) at Ponckhockie
column3: at the junction of the Rondout Creek and the Hudson River. They traded European goods with the Lenape and Mohican for the furs their trappers collected. The first recorded permanent settler in what would become the city of Kingston was Thomas Chambers. He came from the area of Rensselaerswyck in 1653. The new settlement was called Esopus after the local Lenape people.

column2: European settlers began buying land in what now is Kingston from the Esopus Indians
column3: although historians believe the two cultures had drastically different conceptions of property and land use. Tension between the two cultures rose quickly as a result.

column1: Common sources of friction between Dutch settlers and the Esopus included settlers' livestock trampling Indian cornfields
column2: disputes over trade
column3: and the adverse effects of Dutch brandy on the Native Americans. Prior to the Europeans' arrival
column4: they had no experience with liquor. In the spring of 1658
column5: Peter Stuyvesant
column6: Director-General of New Amsterdam
column7: ordered the consolidation and fortification of the settlement on high ground in what today is Uptown Kingston. The building of the defensive Stockade increased the conflicts. Tensions broke out is the Esopus Wars.In 1661 the settlement was granted a charter as a separate municipality; Stuyvesant named it Wiltwijck (Wiltwyck). It was not until 1663 that the Dutch ended the four-year conflict with the Esopus
column8: defeating them with a coalition of Dutch settlers

column1: Wiltwyck was one of three large Hudson River settlements in New Netherland
column2: the other two being Beverwyck
column3: now Albany; and New Amsterdam
column4: now New York City. With the English seizure of New Netherland in 1664
column5: relations between the Dutch settlers and the English soldiers garrisoned there were often strained. In 1669
column6: the English renamed Wiltwyck as Kingston
column7: in honor of the family seat of Governor Lovelace's mother. In 1683
column8: citizens of Kingston petitioned the Kingston court to buy more land from the Esopus people. Officials from Ulster County maintained contact with the Esopus until 1727.Many descendants of the Esopus people who inhabited the area became remnant members of several other related
column9: displaced tribes. Some in the diaspora are among the federally recognized Stockbridge–Munsee Community
column10: who moved from New York to Shawano County
column11: Wisconsin; the Munsee-Delaware of the Six Nations Reserve in Ontario
column13: established after the Revolution by the Crown for its Iroquois and other Indian allies; and the Ramapough Lenape Indian Nation (located primarily in the highland of the New York-New Jersey border area).

column2: Kingston was designated as the first capital of the state of New York. During the summer of 1777
column3: when the New York State constitution was being written
column4: New York City was occupied by British troops. Albany (then the second-largest settlement in New York and capital of the newly independent State of New York) was under threat of attack by the British. The seat of government was moved to Kingston
column5: which was deemed safer.

column2: having been stopped at Saratoga
column3: but they did reach Kingston. On October 13
column5: the city was burned by British troops moving up river from New York City
column6: and disembarking at the mouth of the Rondout Creek at "Ponckhockie". The residents of Kingston knew about the oncoming fleet. By the time the British arrived
column7: the residents and government officials had removed to Hurley
column8: New York. The Kingston area was largely agricultural and a major granary for the colonies at the time
column9: so the British burned large amounts of wheat and all but one or two of the buildings. Kingston celebrates and re-enacts the 1777 burning of the city by the British every other year. (2019 is the year for the next "burning" of Kingston)
column10: in a citywide theatrical staging of the event that begins at the Rondout.)

column1: Kingston was incorporated as a village on April 6
column2: 1805. In the early 1800s
column3: four sloops plied the river
column4: carrying passengers and freight from Kingston to New York. By 1829
column5: river steamers made the trip to Manhattan in a little over twelve hours
column6: usually travelling by night. Columbus Point (now known as Kingston Point) was the river landing for Kingston
column7: and stage lines ran from the village to the Point. The Dutch cultural influence in Kingston remained strong through the end of the nineteenth century.

column1: Rondout was a small farming village until 1825
column2: when construction of the Delaware and Hudson Canal from Rondout to Honesdale
column3: Pennsylvania
column4: attracted an influx of laborers. When they completed the canal in 1828
column5: Rondout became an important tidewater coal terminal. Natural cement deposits were found throughout the valley
column6: and in 1844 quarrying began in the "Ponchockie" section of Rondout. The Newark Lime and Cement Company shipped cement throughout the United States
column7: a thriving business until the invention of cheaper
column8: quicker drying Portland Cement. Workers cut and stored ice from the Hudson River each winter
column9: keeping it in large warehouses of ice near the river. The ice would be cut in chunks and delivered to customers around the city. It was preserved in straw all year and ice chunks served as an early method of refrigeration.Large brick making factories also were built near this shipping hub. Rondout's primacy as a shipping hub ended with the advent of railroads. These lines were built through Rondout and Kingston
column10: with stations in each place. They could also transport their loads through the city without stopping.

column1: Wilbur (aka Twaalfskill) was a hamlet upstream from Rondout
column2: where the Twaalfskill Creek met the Rondout Creek. There was a sloop landing there. The hamlet became the center for the shipment of bluestone to lay the sidewalks of New York City.

column1: Kingston officially became a city on May 29
column3: with the merger of the villages of Rondout and Kingston
column4: and the hamlet of Wilbur.

column1: Kingston is home to many historic churches. The oldest is the First Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of Kingston
column2: which was organized in 1659. Referred to as The Old Dutch Church
column3: it is in uptown Kingston.  George Clinton
column4: first governor of New York and fourth US vice president
column5: is buried in the churchyard. Many of the city's historic churches are on Wurts street (six are in one block). What is now called the Hudson Valley Wedding Chapel was built in 1867; it has been restored and is used for weddings.

column1: Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church at 75 Spring Street was founded in 1842. The original church building at the corner of Hunter and Ravine streets burned to the ground in the late 1850s. The current church on Spring Street was built in 1874.
St. John's Episcopal Church was named for St. John the Evangelist. It was founded in 1832
column2: on June 24
column3: the feast of St. John the Baptist. Therefore
column4: both are considered patrons of the parish. Rev. Reuben Sherwood of Saugerties
column5: New York was the first rector. The first church was built on Wall Street and opened November 24

column2: the property was sold to the Up-to-Date clothing company. The church structure was dismantled and relocated to Albany Ave. In 1992
column3: St. John's established "Angel Food East"
column4: a ministry that delivers food prepared at the church kitchen to persons in need throughout Ulster County.

column2: Lewis T. Wattson
column3: rector of St. John's
column4: established the Church of the Holy Cross as a mission of St. John's
column5: to serve working-class families living near the West Shore Railroad. Many of them worked for the railroad. Holy Cross had a more Anglo-Catholic tradition and a particular mission to the poor. Since the late 20th century
column6: given increased Latinx immigration from Mexico
column8: Holy Cross/Santa Cruz has become a bilingual (Spanish/English)

column1: St. Joseph's Parish began in 1863 as a one-room Roman Catholic mission school to serve the children of the Wilbur area. It was founded by Father Felix Farrelly
column2: pastor of St. Mary's Parish in Rondout. The building was later sold to the city of Kingston in 1871.In 1867
column3: Rev. James Coyne was appointed pastor of St. Mary's in Rondout. The following year he established St. Joseph's in Kingston. He purchased the Young Men's Gymnasium on the corner of Fair and Bowery streets. The first Mass was said on September 21
column4: 1868 by Fr. James Dougherty
column5: an alumnus of St. Mary's parochial school. Dougherty became the first pastor of St. Joseph's parish. Fr. Dougherty is buried in St. Mary's Cemetery.

column1: As the chapel was deemed too small
column2: the parish purchased the former Kingston Armory at the corner of Wall and Main streets for use as a church. Many new Catholic immigrants had arrived in the mid-century from Ireland and southern and eastern Europe. The new church was dedicated on July 26
column3: 1869. In 1877 Jockey Hill was made a mission of St. Joseph's. In 1962 a mission was established in Hurley.

column2: St. Joseph's Church underwent a major renovation
column3: including the installation of the side altars. The new church front was completed in 1898. The interior was renovated in 1905.The frame building on the Bowery was adapted as a schoolhouse. This was replaced in 1905 with the acquisition of the former mansion of Judge Alton B. Parker at 1 Pearl Street
column4: for a new St. Joseph's School and Convent. The Fair Street school building continued to be used as the parish hall until the property was sold in 1911. Also in 1911 a site for a larger school and convent was secured and 1 Pearl Street was sold. In 1943 the Sisters of St. Ursula replaced the Sisters of Charity at the school.

column2: construction began on the current St Joseph School
column3: which housed eight additional classrooms. Old St. Joseph School was renamed as the Msgr. Stephen Connolly Bldg. A plaque donated by the Holy Name Society in honor of Father John Broidy
column4: the pastor who oversaw construction of the building in 1912
column5: is installed on the right front of the building.

column1: Kingston has three recognized area neighborhoods. The Uptown Stockade Area
column2: The Midtown Area
column3: and The Downtown Waterfront Area. The Uptown Stockade District was the first capital of New York State. Meanwhile
column4: the Midtown area is known for its early 20th century industries and is home to the Ulster Performing Arts Center and the historic City Hall building.

column2: once the village of Rondout and now the Rondout-West Strand Historic District
column3: borders the Rondout Creek and includes a recently redeveloped waterfront. The creek empties into the Hudson River through a large
column4: protected tidal area which was the terminus of the Delaware and Hudson Canal
column5: built to haul coal from Pennsylvania to New York City.The Rondout neighborhood is known for its artists' community and its many art galleries; in 2007 Business Week online named it as among "America's best places for artists." It is also the site of a number of festivals
column6: including the Kingston Jazz Festival and the Artists Soapbox Derby.Midtown is the largest of Kingston's neighborhoods
column7: home to Kingston High School and both campuses of HealthAlliance Hospital
column8: part of the Westchester Medical Center Health Network; HealthAlliance Broadway Campus (formerly The Kingston Hospital) and HealthAlliance Mary's Avenue Campus (formerly Benedictine Hospital).

column1: While the Uptown area is noted for its "antique" feeling
column2: the overhangs attached to buildings along Wall and North Front streets were added to historic buildings in the late 1970s and are not authentically part of the 19th century Victorian architecture. The historic covered storefront walks
column3: known as the Pike Plan
column4: were recently reinforced and modernized with skylights. In the Stockade district of Uptown
column5: many 17th century stone buildings remain. Among these is the Senate House
column6: which was built in the 1670s and was used as the state capitol during the revolution. Many of these old buildings were burned by the British Oct. 17
column8: and restored later. A controversial restoration of 1970s-era canopies was marred by the sudden appearance of painted red goats on planters just prior to the neighborhood's rededication. This part of the city is also the location of the Ulster County Office Building.

column1: The Kingston Tigers are the city high school's sports teams.

Kingston Stockade FC is a men's semi-professional soccer club that competes in the National Premier Soccer League (NPSL) in the 4th division of the US soccer pyramid. Kingston Stockade FC play their home games at Dietz Stadium.In 1921
column2: one time major league player Dutch Schirick organized a semi-professional team
column3: the Colonels
column4: in Kingston
column5: New York. Major league teams would
column6: on occasion
column7: play exhibition games against the Kingston Colonels
column8: and would sometimes recruit local talent. Bud Culloton became a pitcher for the Pittsburgh Pirates.

column1: The government of Kingston consists of a mayor and city council known as the Common Council. The Common Council consists of 10 members
column2: nine of which are elected from wards while one is elected at large. The mayor is elected in a citywide vote every four years.

column1: Steve Noble was elected to the mayoral post in 2015.List of Mayors:
The Kingston City School District contains seven elementary schools
column2: two middle schools
column3: and one high school.

column1: Kingston High School is the city's public high schoolThe Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York operates Catholic schools in Ulster County. Most students at John A. Coleman Catholic High School reside within the Kingston city school district. Kingston Catholic School is also in the community.
St. Joseph School in Kingston had 267 students in 2007. It was originally scheduled to close in 2013. However the archdiocese reversed course and allowed it to stay open. However
column2: in 2017 the school ultimately did close. By spring 2017 the school had 146 students. The would-be enrollment had dropped to 90 for the 2017–2018 school year. Kingston Catholic School acquired the newer St. Joseph building and turned it into its middle school facility. The older building was put up for sale in 2019.The Kingston Center of SUNY Ulster (KCSU) is a branch of the county's community college that offers programs
column3: courses and certifications at a convenient Midtown location. KCSU is the new home for Police Basic Training and also offers human services
column4: criminal justice and the general education courses required by the State of New York to satisfy the liberal arts core of an A.A. or A.S. degree.

column1: Commuter service is available by bus to New York City daily via Trailways of New York. The 90-mile trip takes roughly two hours by motor coach.
Passenger railroad service to Kingston Union Station was discontinued in 1958 when the New York Central Railroad ended passenger service on the West Shore Railroad
column2: which ran on an Albany—Kingston—Newburgh -- Weehawken
column3: New Jersey itinerary. Amtrak maintains service on the east side of the Hudson. The Rhinecliff-Kingston Amtrak station is about 11 miles (20 km) away
column4: and there is also access to Amtrak at the Poughkeepsie station
column5: on the east bank of the Hudson and about 17 miles (30 km). That station also serves Metro-North trains.

column1: CSX Transportation operates freight rail service through Kingston on the River Line Subdivision. A small rail yard of about 7 tracks is operated in Kingston.

column2: 4.32 miles (6.95 km) to the north
column3: carries New York State Route 199 and is the nearest bridge traversing the Hudson River. U.S. Highway 9W runs north–south through the city. The New York State Thruway
column4: also known at this section as Interstate 87
column5: runs through the western part of the city.

column1: The area is served by Kingston-Ulster airport (20N)
column2: located at the western base of the Kingston-Rhinecliff bridge. The nearest major airports to Kingston are Stewart International Airport 39 miles (62.8 km) south in Newburgh
column3: and Albany International Airport
column4: approximately 65 mi (105 km) north.The three major metropolitan airports for New York City are located on western Long Island: LaGuardia Airport approximately 80 mi (129 km) south and John F. Kennedy International approximately 93 mi (150 km) south
column5: and in New Jersey: Newark Liberty International is approximately 86 mi (138 km) south.

column1: Local travel is supported by the city-owned CitiBus system (headquarters at 420 Broadway) provides city bus service
column2: and Ulster County Area Transit (UCAT) provides service to points elsewhere in Ulster County. Route A travels between Kingston Plaza and Riverfront
column3: B between Albany Avenue and Fairview Avenue
column4: and C between Golden Hill and Port Ewen.On the first Saturday of every month
column5: an "art bus"
column6: usually a CitiBus tourist trolley
column7: takes passengers on a guided tour of the art galleries of Kingston. The fare is $1. Kingston's art galleries all have openings on the first Saturday of the month.

column1: Weekend water taxi service between Kingston and Rhinecliff
column2: New York is available May through October for $10 round-trip.  Some trips stop at the Rondout Light; a tour is available for an additional $5.Kingston historically was an important transportation center for the region. The Hudson River
column3: Rondout Creek and Delaware and Hudson Canal were important commercial waterways. At one time
column4: Kingston was served by four railroad companies and two trolley lines. Kingston has been designated as a New York State Heritage Area
column5: with a transportation theme. The Hudson River Maritime Museum and Trolley Museum of New York are located along the waterfront and help interpret this historic role.

column2: a scenic railroad company
column3: runs trains from Kingston on the former Ulster and Delaware right of way.
